channel.title: Comments on: OLE LotusScript Class to read and write to Excel

item.title: By: Chris Crompton
item.dc:creator: Chris Crompton
item.description: <p>Thanks for the great ExcelClass! It is very simple to use. One thing I need is to be able to insert a new column at a certain location in the file (I'm starting with a "template"). Do you know the line or two of code that would accomplish this?</p>
item.content:encoded: Thanks for the great ExcelClass! It is very simple to use. One thing I need is to be able to insert a new column at a certain location in the file (I’m starting with a “template”). Do you know the line or two of code that would accomplish this?

item.title: By: Matt White
item.dc:creator: Matt White
item.description: <p>Thanks for spotting the "deliberate" mistakes Matthias! I have corrected them now.</p>
item.content:encoded: Thanks for spotting the “deliberate” mistakes Matthias! I have corrected them now.

item.title: By: Matthias TMC
item.dc:creator: Matthias TMC
item.description: <p>Matt,<br/>Thanks for this helpfull little class.</p><p>Just 2 remarks:<br/>a) In the example, you use "End For" for the end of the loop. As far as I know is this not supported in LotusScript, so just "Next" or "Next iRow" should be used there.<br/>b) In the example, the report variable is not declared previously which will cause an error - at least if Option Declare is used.</p>
item.content:encoded:
Matt,
Thanks for this helpfull little class.

Just 2 remarks:
a) In the example, you use “End For” for the end of the loop. As far as I know is this not supported in LotusScript, so just “Next” or “Next iRow” should be used there.
b) In the example, the report variable is not declared previously which will cause an error – at least if Option Declare is used.
